sub_topic: The investigation of the properties of the Higgs boson in different production modes
message_1: What is the difference in decay modes of the Higgs boson particle produced through the fusion of two gluons compared to its production through the fusion of two vector bosons, and how does this affect the detection of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC)?
message_2:
The Higgs boson can be produced through different processes at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Two of these processes are gluon-gluon fusion (ggF) and vector boson fusion (VBF). In both cases, the Higgs boson is produced, and its decay modes are independent of the production mechanism. However, the production rates and the experimental signatures of these processes are different, which affects the detection strategies at the LHC.

In gluon-gluon fusion, two gluons from the colliding protons interact via a loop of heavy quarks (mainly top quarks) to produce a Higgs boson. This process has the highest production rate for the Higgs boson at the LHC, contributing to about 90% of the total Higgs boson production. However, it also has a large background from other processes, making it challenging to identify the Higgs boson signal.

In vector boson fusion, two vector bosons (W or Z) are radiated from the colliding protons, and these bosons interact to produce a Higgs boson. This process has a lower production rate compared to gluon-gluon fusion, but it has a distinct experimental signature: two forward jets with a large rapidity gap between them and the Higgs boson. This signature helps to reduce the background and improve the detection of the Higgs boson.

The decay modes of the Higgs boson are the same regardless of the production mechanism. The most common decay modes are Higgs to bottom quarks (H->bb), Higgs to WW, Higgs to tau leptons (H->ττ), Higgs to ZZ, and Higgs to photons (H->γγ). The choice of decay mode for detection depends on the Higgs boson mass and the experimental conditions at the LHC.

In summary, the difference between the Higgs boson produced through gluon-gluon fusion and vector boson fusion lies in the production rates and experimental signatures, not in the decay modes. These differences affect the detection strategies and the sensitivity to the Higgs boson signal at the LHC.
